news_summary: New discoveries about a neutron star's unusual wind are transforming our understanding of space physics.
news_summary_fr: De nouvelles découvertes sur le vent inhabituel d'une étoile à neutrons transforment notre compréhension de la physique spatiale.
news_summary_es: Nuevos descubrimientos sobre el inusual viento de una estrella de neutrones están transformando nuestra comprensión de la física espacial.

articles.title: A neutron star’s weird wind rewrites space physics
articles.summary: XRISM’s observations of GX13+1 revealed a slow, fog-like wind instead of the expected high-speed blast, challenging existing models of radiation-driven outflows. The discovery hints that temperature differences in accretion discs may determine how energy shapes the cosmos.
articles.content:
The X-Ray Imaging and Spectroscopy Mission (XRISM) has identified a surprising contrast between the winds blasting away from a disk around a neutron star and those seen near supermassive black holes. The neutron star system produces an unusually dense outflow that challenges current ideas about how these winds form and how they reshape their surroundings.

On February 25, 2024, XRISM used its Resolve instrument to observe the neutron star GX13+1, the compact remnant of a once larger star. GX13+1 shines brightly in X-rays that come from an accretion disk of superheated material spiraling inward and striking the star's surface.

These inward flows can also launch powerful outflows that alter the space around them. How these outflows arise is still under investigation, which is why the team targeted GX13+1.

Resolve can precisely measure the energy of individual X-ray photons, so the scientists anticipated seeing fine-grained details that had never been captured before.

"When we first saw the wealth of details in the data, we felt we were witnessing a game-changing result," says Matteo Guainazzi, ESA XRISM project scientist. "For many of us, it was the realization of a dream that we had chased for decades."

Why cosmic winds matter

These winds are not just curiosities. They drive large-scale change in the universe.

Similar winds also blow from systems with supermassive black holes at galaxy centers. They can compress giant molecular clouds to trigger star birth or heat and disperse those clouds to halt star formation. Astronomers refer to this push and pull as feedback, and in extreme cases the wind from a central black hole can regulate the growth of its entire host galaxy.

Because the processes around supermassive black holes might mirror those near GX13+1, the team chose this neutron star system as a closer, brighter target that could reveal the underlying physics in sharper detail.

A timely surge to the Eddington limit

Just before the planned observations, GX13+1 unexpectedly brightened and reached or even surpassed the Eddington limit.

This limit describes what happens as matter falls onto a compact object such as a black hole or a neutron star. More infalling matter releases more energy. As the energy output rises, the radiation exerts pressure on the incoming material and pushes it outward. At the Eddington limit, the high-energy light being produced can drive almost all of the infalling matter back into space as a wind.

Resolve recorded GX13+1 during this dramatic phase.

"We could not have scheduled this if we had tried," said Chris Done, Durham University, UK, the lead researcher on the study. "The system went from about half its maximum radiation output to something much more intense, creating a wind that was thicker than we'd ever seen before."

A slow, dense wind defies expectations

Despite the intense outburst, the wind's speed remained near 1 million km/h. That is swift on Earth but slow compared with winds near the Eddington limit around supermassive black holes, where outflows can reach 20 to 30 percent of light speed, more than 200 million km/h.

"It is still a surprise to me how 'slow' this wind is," says Chris, "as well as how thick it is. It's like looking at the Sun through a bank of fog rolling towards us. Everything goes dimmer when the fog is thick."

Neutron star vs black hole winds

This was not the only contrast. Earlier XRISM observations of a supermassive black hole at the Eddington limit revealed an ultrafast, clumpy wind. By comparison, the outflow from GX13+1 appears slow and smooth.

"The winds were utterly different but they're from systems which are about the same in terms of the Eddington limit. So if these winds really are just powered by radiation pressure, why are they different?" asks Chris.

Accretion disk temperature as the key

The team suggests the answer lies in the temperature of the accretion disk around the central object. Counterintuitively, disks around supermassive black holes tend to be cooler than those in stellar-mass systems with neutron stars or black holes.

Disks around supermassive black holes are much larger. They can be extremely luminous, yet that power is spread over a vast area, so the typical radiation they emit peaks in ultraviolet light. Stellar-mass systems radiate more strongly in X-rays.

Ultraviolet light interacts with matter more readily than X-rays. Chris and colleagues propose that this difference allows ultraviolet radiation to push material more efficiently, generating the much faster winds seen near supermassive black holes.

What this means for galaxy evolution

If this explanation holds, it will refine how scientists think about the exchange of energy and matter in extreme environments. It could also clarify how these processes influence the growth of galaxies and the broader evolution of the cosmos.

"The unprecedented resolution of XRISM allows us to investigate these objects -- and many more -in far greater detail, paving the way for the next-generation, high-resolution X-ray telescope such as NewAthena," says Camille Diez, ESA Research fellow.

XRISM mission at a glance

XRISM (pronounced krizz-em) launched on September 7, 2023. The mission is led by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) in partnership with NASA and ESA. It flies with two instruments: Resolve, an X-ray calorimeter that measures the energy of individual X-ray photons to deliver an unprecedented level of energy resolution (the capability of an instrument to distinguish the X-ray 'colors'), and Xtend, a wide-field X-ray CCD camera that images the surrounding region.

This breakthrough has broad implications for understanding the cosmos and energy-matter exchange in extreme environments, representing a meaningful advancement in space science.
articles.personality_title: New space mission finds surprising slow winds around neutron star
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study powerful winds of gas blown away from dense objects in space like neutron stars and black holes. These winds shape their surroundings and affect how galaxies grow. The XRISM mission, launched in 2023, uses special instruments to closely observe X-rays emitted by such objects to learn more about these winds.

**What happened** – On February 25, 2024, XRISM’s Resolve instrument observed a neutron star called GX13+1 during a rare bright phase. Instead of the fast winds expected, it found a slow, thick, fog-like wind moving at about 1 million km/h. This was much slower than the winds seen near supermassive black holes, which can reach speeds over 200 million km/h.

**Impact** – This discovery challenges current ideas that radiation pressure alone drives these winds. Scientists think the difference comes from how hot the disk of material around the star is. The neutron star’s disk is hotter and emits mostly X-rays, while disks around big black holes are cooler and emit ultraviolet light, which pushes gas more strongly. Understanding this helps explain how energy moves in space and affects galaxy growth.

**What's next step** – Researchers will use XRISM and future missions like NewAthena to study more objects in detail. They want to confirm how disk temperature influences wind speed and improve models of how these winds work. This will deepen knowledge about how galaxies and cosmic structures evolve over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – XRISM’s discovery of slow, dense winds around a neutron star reveals that the temperature of surrounding disks plays a key role in shaping cosmic outflows and galaxy evolution.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle mission spatiale découvre des vents lents surprenants autour d'une étoile à neutrons
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les vents puissants de gaz soufflés par des objets denses dans l’espace, comme les étoiles à neutrons et les trous noirs. Ces vents façonnent leur environnement et influencent la croissance des galaxies. La mission XRISM, lancée en 2023, utilise des instruments spéciaux pour observer de près les rayons X émis par ces objets afin d’en apprendre plus sur ces vents.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 25 février 2024, l’instrument Resolve de XRISM a observé une étoile à neutrons appelée GX13+1 pendant une phase rare de forte luminosité. Au lieu des vents rapides attendus, il a détecté un vent lent et dense, semblable à un brouillard, se déplaçant à environ 1 million de km/h. C’était beaucoup plus lent que les vents près des trous noirs supermassifs, qui peuvent dépasser 200 millions de km/h.

**Impact** – Cette découverte remet en question l’idée que seule la pression de radiation pousse ces vents. Les scientifiques pensent que la différence vient de la température du disque de matière autour de l’étoile. Le disque de l’étoile à neutrons est plus chaud et émet surtout des rayons X, tandis que les disques autour des gros trous noirs sont plus froids et émettent des rayons ultraviolets, qui poussent le gaz plus efficacement. Comprendre cela aide à expliquer comment l’énergie circule dans l’espace et influence la croissance des galaxies.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs utiliseront XRISM et des missions futures comme NewAthena pour étudier plus d’objets en détail. Ils veulent confirmer comment la température du disque influence la vitesse des vents et améliorer les modèles sur leur fonctionnement. Cela approfondira la connaissance de l’évolution des galaxies et des structures cosmiques.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La découverte par XRISM de vents lents et denses autour d’une étoile à neutrons montre que la température des disques environnants joue un rôle clé dans la formation des vents cosmiques et l’évolution des galaxies.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva misión espacial descubre vientos lentos sorprendentes alrededor de una estrella de neutrones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian los fuertes vientos de gas que soplan desde objetos densos en el espacio, como estrellas de neutrones y agujeros negros. Estos vientos moldean su entorno y afectan el crecimiento de las galaxias. La misión XRISM, lanzada en 2023, utiliza instrumentos especiales para observar de cerca los rayos X emitidos por estos objetos y aprender más sobre estos vientos.

**Qué pasó** – El 25 de febrero de 2024, el instrumento Resolve de XRISM observó una estrella de neutrones llamada GX13+1 durante una fase brillante poco común. En lugar de los vientos rápidos esperados, encontró un viento lento y denso, parecido a una niebla, que se movía a alrededor de 1 millón de km/h. Esto es mucho más lento que los vientos cerca de agujeros negros supermasivos, que pueden superar los 200 millones de km/h.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento desafía la idea de que solo la presión de radiación impulsa estos vientos. Los científicos creen que la diferencia está en la temperatura del disco de material alrededor de la estrella. El disco de la estrella de neutrones es más caliente y emite principalmente rayos X, mientras que los discos alrededor de grandes agujeros negros son más fríos y emiten luz ultravioleta, que empuja el gas con más fuerza. Entender esto ayuda a explicar cómo se mueve la energía en el espacio y cómo afecta el crecimiento de las galaxias.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores usarán XRISM y futuras misiones como NewAthena para estudiar más objetos en detalle. Quieren confirmar cómo la temperatura del disco influye en la velocidad del viento y mejorar los modelos sobre cómo funcionan estos vientos. Esto profundizará el conocimiento sobre la evolución de galaxias y estructuras cósmicas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El descubrimiento de XRISM de vientos lentos y densos alrededor de una estrella de neutrones revela que la temperatura de los discos que la rodean juega un papel clave en la formación de vientos cósmicos y la evolución de las galaxias.
